texts.shortText: Beetles of the family Staphylinidae (‘rove beetles’) are fairly easily recognized as a group, in that most have narrow bodies and very short wing-covers, leaving the elongate abdomen largely exposed. However, as most species are very small, and many different genera are found on the seashore, species level identification is challenging. The tiny species depicted here is usually referred to as ‘Bledius sp’ and is best recognized by its unusual habits of creating dense networks of mole-like surface burrows on the upper tidal levels of sheltered sandy beaches.

Difficult to establish, as species not identified

Global: Unknown.

Local/Regional:  Common on sheltered beaches along west and south coast, including in estuaries.

Colonises the upper intertidal sections of fine-grained sandy beaches. Seldom noticed due to their small size and narrow bodies (meaning that they pass thought the collecting nets and sieves used by most researchers) but can be extremely common, reaching densities of thousands per square meter. At high tide, adults retreat into vertical burrows, which trap a bubble of air to breath while underwater. When the tide recedes they emerge and construct mole-like burrows just beneath the sand surface, picking up and cleaning individual sand grains of diatoms etc before packing them above their heads. Within a few hours the entire sand surface can become crazed with their meandering burrows. As the tide rises again they retreat back into their burrows. Best collected by digging up the sand and tossing this into a dish or puddle of water – the sand sinks while the beetles float!
Feed on diatoms attached to the sand grains.

The South African species has not been studied, but similar species from the USA lay their eggs attached to individual sand grains on the burrow wall. Small larvae occupy the maternal burrow, but larger larvae establish their own burrows and appear to feed in the same way as adults. Pupation also takes place in the sand.

Staphylinid beetles are extremely common in intertidal habitats and hundreds of coastal species are known globally. The South African fauna is poorly described and many species remain un-named. Although several other staphylinid species are found associated with rotting algae in the region this one is easily recognized by the shallow meandering surface burrows it makes on fine, clean sand.
